questions.question_text:
A small government organization wants to implement stateless desktops using VMware products. The IT team is unable to add or alter any GPO in the organization's Active Directory. It wants to minimize the storage space required for the user VMs and preserve user's profiles and other personalization settings.
Which accomplishes these goals?

choices.D: Horizon Linked Clones desktop pools with persistent disks
choices.A: Horizon Instant Clone desktop pools with VMware User Environment Manager
choices.B: Horizon RDS desktop pools with App Volumes Writable Volumes
choices.C: Horizon Full VM desktop pools with App Volumes Writable Volumes

discussion.content: I think A is correct

D
They want stateless desktops so LC or IC, but cannot alter or add GPO so UEM is out since that is needed to preserve user profiles and other settings with UEM.
Linked Clones will still minimize storage space and persistent disks allow preserving profiles and personalization settings.

questions.question_text:
A customer is deploying Horizon View 7.1 utilizing a Cloud Prod Architecture. The customer wants to utilize 32-node clusters, and a single vCenter at each site to support 9,500 desktops per site.
Which two statements about this configuration are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
his request arises from the fact that a single instance of vCenter Server can support 10,000 virtual machines. With View 5.2 and later, customers have the ability to use a single vCenter Server to manage a 10,000-desktop environment. 
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Horizon-7/7.1/com.vmware.horizon-view.planning.doc/GUID-CE4019FE-0C43-462A-A08E-82357B1CAF8B.html

AB

Selected Answer: BD
A - Incorrect. There is nothing in the question/statement where we can determine if this is true or not
B - Correct. We're building a cloud pod, so you can combine pools.
C - Incorrect. Maximum vSphere cluster is 32
D - Correct. A Horizon block supports 2000 users. Yes you can build multiple blocks into a pod, but the answer specifically says BLOCK not pod.

A B is Correct
From "view-71-architecture-planning"
A building block consists of physical servers, a vSphere infrastructure, View servers, shared storage, and virtual machine desktops for end users. A building block is a logical construct and should not be sized for more than 2,000 View desktops. Customers usually include up to five building blocks in a View pod,
although in theory you can use more blocks than that, as long as the pod does not go above 10,000 sessions and 7 View Connection Server instances.

Wrong
C. This configuration requires a 64-node cluster per site.
-> vSphere clusters can contain up to 32 ESXi hosts
D. This configuration exceeds the maximum supported size for a View block. 
-> A building block is a logical construct and should not be sized for more than 2,000 View desktops.

comments.content:
One block contain one vCenter, so you know how any block will be deployed...
Agree with B D

But there is no statement about how many block are to be used in each site, is there? Which means you could potentially have 5 blocks per site and still be in a supported configuration: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Horizon-7/7.2/com.vmware.horizon-view.planning.doc/GUID-3FE970DF-382D-4F2A-B2E6-24B670B6705B.html

discussion.content: In my studies I came to the conclusion that they are questions B and D, according to the limitation of 2000 desktops per Block.

choices.C: This configuration requires a 64-node cluster per site.
choices.D: This configuration exceeds the maximum supported size for a View block.
choices.B: This configuration allows multiple pools to be grouped together using global entitlements.
choices.A: This configuration allows all desktops at a site to be provisioned from a single master image.

questions.question_text:
An application packaging team is preparing to deploy a new enterprise application for 1000 users.
Application requirements and limitations include:
✑ Windows 2012 R2 or Windows 10 64-bit OS
✑ Installation of a PDF printer
✑ Application only allows a single instance to be launched
✑ 1 GB RAM
The organization is only using Horizon hosted applications on Windows 2012 R2. The servers are at 30% utilization. No additional users will be added.
What changes to the Horizon environment will be required to deploy the application?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Since only 1 instance of the app is allowed to run, RDSH is out. A new desktop pool is required.
Anti-affinity is only limit how many same apps can run on one rdsh.not a user can run how many same apps.

i agree with NNy. I'm chose C
Anti-affinity rules can be created on the pool to limit 1 launch
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Horizon/2106/published-desktops-applications/GUID-49E7BE66-A3A6-47E8-A2BD-42DF4D5FE50B.html

B & D are not options.
You cannot have multiple instances running so C is not an option. You could do it if session-based desktops were an option, but C only says "new APPLICATION pool"
Thus, A seems to be the only viable option to meet the requirements.

it is an enterprise application for a 1000 users AND it can only have a single instance. Then we cannot host this on RDS servers as you would need a 1000 servers!
The only other option here is Horizon Desktop Pool which is expensive way of running one app
Good thought. Anti-affinity rules can be created on the pool to limit 1 launch and installing the PDF printer on the RDS host should work then you won't need UEM/DEM
i would choose C, because servers are not overloaded, and PDF Printer can be implemented on Windows 2012R2

questions.question_text:
After implementing App Volumes and configuring all of the AppStacks, customers are complaining about slow login times. All AppStacks are hosted on the SAN and each AppStack is assigned to 700 users and includes a minimum of 3 applications per AppStack.
What cost effective change can an architect recommend to improve the issue?

discussion.content:
C "Enable the Mount on Host Command to improve performance."
Mount on Host – Allows App Volumes to issue a mount command directly to the ESXi hosts instead of issuing the command through vCenter Server. App Volumes attaches AppStacks and writable volumes directly to the ESXi hosts. This option shortens the command path and time to mount.
https://techzone.vmware.com/resource/reviewers-guide-vmware-app-volumes#:~:text=Mount%20on%20Host%20%E2%80%93%20Allows%20App,path%20and%20time%20to%20mount.

choices.C: Enable the Mount on Host Command to improve performance.
choices.A: Edit the AppStack and remove some of the applications so that each AppStack only has one application within the AppStack.
choices.D: Increase the RAM in each of the host and assign more vRAM to each Desktop.
choices.B: Install more SSD disks in the SAN to improve performance.
